objtitle.title: *Satan Calling Up His Legions, an Experiment Picture*

objdescid.compdate: c. 1799-1805Butlin 661 dates the work to c. 1795-1800, but we believe that Blake did not begin executing his tempera paintings until c. 1799. A probable ending date for work on this painting is c. 1805 or even later. In his 1809 *Descriptive Catalogue*, Blake states that the work was "painted at intervals, for experiment on colours" (page 54).

objinfo.medium: water-based tempera with a glue and/or gum binder and with some pen and ink outlining and shell gold or gold leaf

provenance.name: Victoria and Albert Museum
provenance.note: Acquired by Samuel Palmer no later than 1876 and possibly much earlier, directly from Blake or his wife Catherine; probably Samuel Palmer's son, Alfred Herbert Palmer, by inheritance in 1881; sold anonymously, Christie's, 20 March 1882, lot 109 (£13.13s. to "Dowdeswell," probably a dealer); the dealer E. Parsons, sold 30 June 1910 to W. Graham Robertson; offered Christie's, 22 July 1949, lot 55 (bought-in at £73.10s.); given by the executors of Robertson's estate to the Victoria and Albert Museum in 1950.
